text: 'Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of public check-ins – telling everyone online where you are. The website's message was clear: you might think you are just saying, ‘Hey, I’m here’ – but you are also telling everyone, including people you might not want to meet. This showed that sharing too much online can be risky. The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with the world: Wealth! Fame! So, we share our secrets, photos, and stories online. But then we find out it can be dangerous and confusing. Is this sad? Maybe, but don’t worry. There is a way to understand this future, thanks to some early internet users. In the early days of the web, they explored these dangers. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with being famous – all before social media existed. These early users, called bloggers, have already experienced what we are going through now. We should learn from them. In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting on the ‘WWW’, as it was called then. The web was created at Cern, a physics lab in Switzerland, for researchers to share their work. Hall saw it as a way to share his life. He created a detailed story of his life with words and pictures. In January 1996, he started a daily blog, and many people read about his life. Hall shared everything: if you met him, you might be on his site; no topic was off-limits. This was the work of someone who liked attention, but it was also like art. One day, people saw his site was gone, replaced by a sad video called Dark Night. He had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it online, he was told ‘either the blog goes, or I do’. He said, ‘it makes people not trust me’. The blog stopped, but the problem is still here. Sharing online is fun. But if you think it will make people like you, you might be wrong. In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a young web worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job. One day, a colleague sent her blog to the bosses, and she lost her job. People who study online behavior call this the ‘online distribution effect’: we feel we can say things online that we wouldn’t say in person. But the web is not a place where we can say anything without consequences. Our online lives are connected to our real lives. If we forget this, we can make big mistakes. Armstrong’s story ended well. She was upset and stopped blogging for a while, but she got married and started her blog again, writing about her family. Now she is a famous ‘mommy blogger’ and her blog supports her family. She learned that just because we can say anything online, doesn’t mean we should.'

Some time ago, scientists started a campaign to warn people about a low-budget film called "What the Bleep Do We Know?" This film mixed documentary and drama to show that there is a lot about our universe we don't understand. Scientists usually agree with this idea because no one knows everything about the universe. However, some scientists were worried about the film and called it "atrocious" and "dangerous." 
At first, the film seemed harmless. Scientists in the film said that new discoveries show the universe is stranger than we thought. But then, the film talked about discoveries like water molecules being changed by thoughts. A Japanese researcher claimed that the shape of a water molecule could change just by the thoughts of people around it. The film showed pictures of ice crystals looking nice after being talked to by someone happy and looking bad after being exposed to someone in a bad mood. 
Many people found this evidence convincing, but scientists were skeptical. They wanted more proof that thoughts can affect water. Pretty pictures of crystals were not enough for them. 
The film's claims were not strange enough. Scientists have found that the universe is made of unknown matter and is expanding because of a mysterious force called "dark energy." These discoveries are based on years of research. 
Other amazing discoveries are being made. Neuroscientists found that our brain takes about half a second to process events, but we don't notice this delay. Anthropologists think they know where modern humans first lived and why they moved to other places. Some scientists believe there are links between life on Earth and the design of the universe.
Science is not finished. We are still far from knowing everything. New ideas like chaos and quantum uncertainty show that we can't understand everything completely. Scientists are trying to create a "Theory of Everything" to explain all the forces and particles in the universe. Many people think the universe is best described with one word: incredible.

'For me, writing novels is hard, but writing short stories is fun. Writing a novel is like planting a forest, and writing a short story is like planting a garden. Both are important and make a beautiful picture together. The trees in the forest give shade, and the wind moves the leaves. In the garden, flowers bloom, and bees and butterflies come. This shows how seasons change. Since I started writing, I switch between novels and short stories. After finishing a novel, I want to write short stories. After short stories, I want to write a novel. I never do both at the same time because they need different thinking. I started with two short novels in 1975, and then from 1984 to 1985, I began writing short stories. It was hard at first, but I enjoyed it. My world of stories grew bigger, and readers liked this new side of me. One of my first stories, ‘Breaking Waves’, was in my first short-story book, Tales from Abroad. Writing short stories is nice because they don’t take long to finish. It usually takes me about a week to make a short story good (though I might change it a lot). It’s not like writing a novel, which takes a year or two. Writing a novel can feel like it goes on forever, and I sometimes wonder if I will finish. So, writing short stories is a nice change. You can make a short story from a small idea, a word, or an image. It’s like jazz music, where the story goes where it wants. If a story doesn’t work, it’s okay. Not every story is great, even for famous writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver. This makes me feel better. I learn from my mistakes and use that in the next story. When I write novels, I try to learn from my short stories. Short stories are like a test place for me. It’s hard to try new things in a novel, so short stories help me. My short stories are like soft shadows or small footprints I leave behind. I remember each one and how I felt when I wrote it. They are like signs to my heart, and I am happy to share these feelings with my readers.'

'Science is a big part of our lives. It can help us understand the world and cure diseases. Science can make life easier, but it can also be dangerous. It tries to explain small things like ants and big things like the universe. Science is not always easy to understand, and sometimes people think it is more or less important than it really is. Scientists often disagree with each other. Old ideas are changed or replaced by new ones. This book talks about ideas in science that changed how we think. We will not focus on everyday things like frying pans. Instead, we will look at ideas and their beauty, but also their limits. Science is always changing. Scientists often find new explanations for things. Sometimes these changes are small, but sometimes they change our beliefs a lot. In the past, people thought the universe was like a big clock. Now, we know that observing the universe can change it. Some people think science cannot explain everything, but it helps us understand more and more. Isaac Newton explained more than Aristotle, and Albert Einstein explained more than Newton. Science makes mistakes, but it keeps going. At the end of the 1800s, people thought there was nothing new to discover in physics. Then, many new things were found, like radioactivity and black holes. Biology also discovered many things. Some people think we will soon understand everything about the universe. Maybe. Science is not just for fun. In the last 200 years, we have started to control nature. Sometimes, we change nature in ways we do not understand. We need to be careful with science. Everyone should know about science because it affects our future. Science is important for our world and our children. It is not just for philosophers. Science can change things like the national budget and our health.'

'Around 2015, after many years of growth, big publishers said that sales of ebooks stopped growing or even went down. This made people question the future of ebooks in the publishing world. One publishing executive said that the excitement about ebooks might have led to bad investments. His company lost some belief in the power of printed books. Even though digital and print books can exist together, people still ask if ebooks will replace print books. This idea makes us think and talk a lot. Why do we see ebooks and print books as fighting each other? The answers tell us about our feelings of excitement and fear about new things. In my research, I found that people often think new technology will replace old ones. Before digital technology, people thought TV would end radio. But radio survived by finding new uses, like listening in cars. The idea of books disappearing is not new. In 1894, people thought the phonograph would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. This has happened many times. Movies, radio, TV, and smartphones were all thought to end print books. Some people thought this would be bad for culture. Others thought ebooks were much better. The idea of books disappearing comes up when new technology appears. This shows our hopes and fears about change. We have strong feelings for things like books and TVs because they are part of our lives. Studies show we connect with objects, like naming our car or getting mad at our computer. New technology, like e-readers, means change. It makes us change our bond with things we use every day. As technology changes, we miss what we used to have. This is why industries make old products popular again. When the printing press spread in 15th-century Europe, people wanted original manuscripts. When movies got sound in the 1920s, people missed silent films. The same happened with digital photography and CDs. E-readers made people appreciate old books and their smell. This should comfort those worried about print books disappearing. But the idea of disappearing media will continue to be a story about technology's power and our dislike of change. We use stories of tragedy and endings to understand change. The story of the death of the book shows our excitement for the future and our fear of losing what we know.'

'Almost every weekday morning for a year and a half, I woke up at 5:30, brushed my teeth, made coffee, and sat down to write. I wrote about how some of the greatest minds in the past 400 years found time each day to do their best work. I looked at their daily schedules to see how they were creative and productive. By writing about the simple details of their daily lives – when they slept, ate, worked, and worried – I wanted to show a new side of their personalities and careers. I wanted to show that they were like us, with habits and routines. The French gastronome Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin once said, ‘Tell me what you eat, and I shall tell you what you are.’ I say, ‘Tell me what time you eat, and if you take a nap afterward.’ This book is about the circumstances of creative activity, not the product. It’s about how people work, not what they create. It’s also personal. The novelist John Cheever thought that even a business letter shows something of your inner self. My book looks at questions I think about in my own life: How do you do meaningful creative work while also earning a living? Is it better to focus completely on a project or to work on it a little each day? When there isn’t enough time for everything, do you give things up like sleep or a clean house, or do you learn to do more in less time? I don’t have all the answers, but I have tried to show examples of how successful people have faced these challenges. I wanted to show how big creative ideas come from small daily actions; how your work habits affect your work, and vice versa. The book’s title is Daily Rituals, but it’s really about people’s routines. A routine can seem ordinary, but it can help you use your time, willpower, and optimism well. A good routine helps you focus and keeps you from being controlled by your moods. The psychologist William James thought you should put part of your life on autopilot; by forming good habits, he said, we can ‘free our minds to advance to really interesting fields of action.’ Ironically, James himself was a procrastinator and couldn’t stick to a regular schedule. This book started because I was procrastinating. One Sunday afternoon, I was alone at the small architecture magazine where I worked, trying to write a story due the next day. Instead of working, I was tidying my desk and making coffee. I’m a ‘morning person’ and can focus well in the morning but not after lunch. That afternoon, to feel better, I searched the Internet for information about other writers’ schedules. I found many interesting stories. I thought someone should collect these stories in one place – so I started the Daily Routines blog that afternoon, and now, this book. The blog was simple; I posted descriptions of people’s routines from biographies, magazine profiles, and newspaper obituaries. For the book, I’ve collected more stories and done more research, while keeping the short and varied voices that made the blog interesting. I’ve let my subjects speak for themselves, using quotes from letters, diaries, and interviews. In other cases, I summarized their routines from other sources. This book wouldn’t be possible without the research of many biographers, journalists, and scholars. I have listed all my sources in the Notes section, which I hope will also guide further reading.'

Howard became a palaeontologist because of something that happened when he was six years old. His father, who was careful with money, said they could not go on holiday to Spain because of money problems. Instead, they went to the English coast. There, Howard found an ammonite* on the beach. From that moment, he knew he wanted to be a palaeontologist. At university, he decided he was interested in the very early history of life, not dinosaurs. He studied small, ancient creatures in rocks.
After finishing his studies, Howard worried about finding a job. He knew he was good, but getting a job was not always fair. When a job at Tavistock College in London was available, he applied. On the day of his interview, the professor who was supposed to help another candidate had an accident and could not attend. Another professor, who did not like the first professor, helped Howard get the job instead. Howard was happy to get the job, even though he later learned it was because of the professors' disagreement.
Howard liked his job, but he knew life could be unpredictable. One day, his briefcase with important lecture notes was stolen at an Underground station. He was upset but went back to the college. There, he met a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. He learned about a new collection of fossils that needed study. This was a big opportunity for him. Because of the theft, he changed his plans. He decided not to go to a conference in Stockholm or take students to Scotland. Instead, he would find a way to visit the museum in Nairobi.

Charles Spence will eat almost anything. "We have ice cream made from bee larvae at home," says the Professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University in the UK. These larvae might look like maggots, but they taste "slightly nutty, floral." Making bug-eating normal is just one of the many food challenges Spence and his team are working on. Spence studies how our senses work together to create the taste of food. His work is changing what we eat and drink, from big food companies to top restaurants. Spence and other scientists study how we experience food and drink. Who we eat with, how food looks, the color and weight of plates, and background noise all change how food tastes. Spence's book, "The Perfect Meal," has many interesting facts about eating. Did you know the first person to order in a restaurant enjoys their food the most? Or that we eat about 35% more when with one other person, and 75% more with three others? Spence's lab in Oxford is simple. There are soundproof booths and old audio-visual equipment. By keeping costs low, he can work with cooks who can't pay for research. Much of his work is funded by a big food company. In the past, research with industry money was not seen as "real science" in universities. But now, universities must show their work has an impact, so this research is important. Spence is helping famous brands reduce salt and sugar. They do it slowly so customers don't notice. If you tell people about the change, they focus on the taste and don't like it as much. Spence met Heston Blumenthal, a famous chef, while working on a project. People used to think science and food didn't mix, but most food is scientific. Blumenthal and Spence created the "Sound of the Sea" dish. Spence says that in the early 1900s, Italian futurists tried similar things, but it didn't become popular. Now, the food industry uses Spence's research everywhere. He found that high-pitched music makes food taste sweeter, and low-pitched sounds make it taste bitter. An airline will soon match music with food for passengers. Last year, a brand released an app that played music while ice cream softened, but they didn't match the music to the taste. At Spence's home, dinner parties are interesting. Once, they ate rabbit with fur on the cutlery. Another time, they used colored lights. They also tested if different drinks have different sounds. For Spence, home, shops, and food events are all part of his lab.

Our brains are busier than ever. We get a lot of information every day, and we have to decide what is important and what is not. We also do more things ourselves now. For example, we book our own flights and find things in shops without help. We try to do many things at once, like work, family, hobbies, and watching TV. Smartphones help us do this, but they also make us think we can do many things at the same time. 
Earl Miller, a scientist at MIT, says our brains are not good at multitasking. When we think we are doing many things at once, we are actually just switching quickly between tasks. This makes us less efficient. Multitasking can also make us stressed and confused. Our brains like new things, so we get distracted easily. 
Glenn Wilson, a psychologist, found that trying to focus on a task while having an unread email can lower our IQ by almost 10 points. Multitasking can be worse for our brains than being tired. Russ Poldrack, a scientist at Stanford, found that learning while multitasking sends information to the wrong part of the brain. For example, if students do homework and watch TV, the information goes to a part of the brain that is not good for facts and ideas.
Making decisions while multitasking is also hard for our brains. Even small decisions can use a lot of brain power. This can lead to bad decisions later. Many people say that email is a big problem because of the large amount of messages we get. We feel we must reply to emails, but it is hard to do this and finish other tasks.

'In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino broke concrete into pieces at night to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In caves in the US, female bats help other bats give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, people did not think these questions were important. Animals had behaviors, and science studied those behaviors. The idea that animals have feelings and thoughts was not taken seriously. But now, this is changing. Research on animals like bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens shows that animals' emotions are being studied more. This change has led to books like Mark Bekoff’s "Wild Justice" and Victoria Braithwaite’s "Do Fish Feel Pain?". These books have started a debate: do animals have feelings and thoughts? This debate leads to another question: do animals know right from wrong? In a study with cows, cows that opened a gate to get food were happier than those that had the gate opened for them. If cows like solving problems, what does this mean for eating beef? People do not agree on what these observations mean. Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, who wrote "Second Nature", thinks we should stop eating meat. He believes we are close to a big change in how we think about animals. Aubrey Manning, a professor, thinks we should rethink how we see animal intelligence. He says animals have a simpler way of thinking than humans. Professor Euan MacPhail thinks we should stop thinking animals are like humans. These experts may never agree because the main issue is not just scientific or moral, but philosophical. It is hard to define what consciousness is, so can we ever know what it is like to be a bat? Balcombe talks about an experiment with starlings, a type of bird, that he thinks shows they can feel sad. At Newcastle University, starlings were put in two groups. One group had nice cages with space and water. The other group had small, empty cages. Both groups learned to eat tasty worms from one box and not eat bad worms from another. Later, when only bad worms were offered, only the birds in nice cages ate them. Balcombe thinks the birds in bad cages felt negative about life. Balcombe, who works with animal rights groups, has strong opinions. He says, ‘We look back at racism with disgust. One day, we will feel the same about how we treat animals. We can’t support animal rights while eating a cheeseburger.’ If Balcombe was the only one with this view, it might be easy to ignore him. But Professor Aubrey Manning agrees with him. Manning wrote a book called "An Introduction to Animal Behaviour". He says, ‘We are seeing a change. In the early 1900s, people thought animals thought like us, then they changed their minds. Now, we are changing again. But it is a difficult topic, and we should avoid personal opinions.’'

'Critical thinking is a way to understand better what we read or listen to. Adrian West, from the Edward de Bono Foundation U.K., says that argument can help find the truth. Technology helps us store and process information, but it might also change how we solve problems. West says we see a lot of poor thinking and opinions that can confuse us. More data does not always mean more knowledge or better decisions. Reading books has gone down by 10%, says the National Endowment for the Arts. Patricia Greenfield, a psychology professor, thinks that focusing more on visual media like TV and video games can reduce critical thinking. She says reading helps imagination and critical thinking, but visual media can improve some information processing. However, most visual media do not give time for reflection or analysis. This can lead to people, especially young ones, not using their full potential. How we see technology affects our views on critical thinking. Video games and learning are a big part of this discussion. James Paul Gee, an educational psychology professor, says video games can be good for learning. Games like Sim City and Civilization teach decision-making and analytical skills. They let players explore ideas in a virtual world. In the digital age, as reading and math scores go down, we need to understand how technology affects thinking.'

'Matthew Crawford is a motorcycle mechanic. He used to work in an office but did not like it. He writes books about how we should live. His first book talks about the good things of working with your hands. His latest book is about how to deal with modern life. He got the idea for this book while shopping. He saw ads on the credit card machine while entering his pin number. Crawford thinks these ads make it hard for us to focus. We cannot choose what to think about because of these distractions. It is hard to remember conversations or think deeply. Because of this, people do not want to talk to strangers anymore. Crawford says we see the world through things like video games and phone apps. These things take over our attention. Many people are worried about this. For example, some office workers complain about emails but still check them in their free time. Studies show that just seeing a phone on the table can distract us. There is no proof yet that our attention spans are shorter, but we are more aware of other things we could be doing. Crawford thinks technology makes us focus too much on ourselves. We have too many choices, which makes it hard to control ourselves. This affects how we interact with others. We prefer texting to talking. Crawford says this is bad for society. He gives an example from his gym. Before, there was one music player for everyone. Now, people use earphones to listen to their own music. The gym is less social now. Crawford suggests two solutions. First, we need rules to reduce noise and distractions in public. Second, we should do activities that make us focus on real things. He mentions cooking, playing ice hockey, and racing motorcycles. These activities help us connect with the real world. They make us use our judgment and work with others. Crawford says these real experiences are better than virtual ones. He does not mean everyone should become a chef. But it is important to find ways to use our judgment. This helps us focus on what matters and makes us less tired from distractions.'

"‘What do you do for a living?’ is a common question. We often talk about our jobs. But when you are a philosopher, like me, it is a bit harder to answer. Saying you are a philosopher can sound a bit too proud. People might think you have special knowledge. This is not true; philosophers are like everyone else. But this idea makes me pause. Why do people think this way about philosophers? One reason is that philosophers often think about what others do and value thinking. The Greek philosopher Aristotle said that a life of thinking is the best life. Not many modern philosophers agree, but philosophy is still linked to thinking. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said, ‘the unexamined life is not worth living’. This means we should think about our lives and not just follow what everyone else does. We can make our own choices by thinking about our lives. But you don’t need to read many books or think deeply all the time. It just means looking at our daily lives to see if they are important. It doesn’t mean living away from people to think. In fact, thinking about life should help us live better and share knowledge. This is important for a good life. Another reason people have the wrong idea about philosophers is that academic philosophy is often far from real life. This is not all the philosophers' fault. Universities focus on expensive and hard-to-read journals. So, philosophers often talk only to other experts. For most people, philosophy seems far from real life. Many philosophers do not try to change this. Universities have made philosophy seem separate, and some philosophers support this. Some areas of philosophy are very technical, and explaining them to non-experts is hard. Philosophy has moved away from society. This needs to change. I sometimes call myself an ‘ethicist’ because I work in ethics, which is about judging human actions. But this title does not fully explain my work. Ethics is often seen as rules and laws. This is a new idea in philosophy. Ethics now often means applied ethics, which looks at if certain actions are fair. These are important questions, and I think about them often. But philosophy is more than this. A discussion might start with whether downloading films illegally is wrong (it is) and then look at responsibility, art, and consumerism. Philosophy helps us look closely at our actions and beliefs. Sometimes we find out things we already know; other times, we see our beliefs are hard to explain. By thinking about these ideas, we help everyone."

'People who love food, like chefs and food lovers, might think that thinking about what and how we eat can make eating more enjoyable. In the past, talking about food was not as important as other big ideas. When philosophers talked about eating, it was often a way to talk about something else, like learning. Sometimes, it seemed like they were talking about food, but they were really discussing other ideas. 
An interesting example is the Greek philosopher Epicurus. He talked about enjoying life and avoiding pain in many ways. But today, his name is often linked to enjoying food and drink. We see his name in restaurants and food shops because people think it makes their food seem special. 
Food is social and cultural. It comes from history and is shared with others. We eat with friends and family, and food is grown and shared in our communities. We interact with food more than anything else, so it is a good topic to think about deeply. 
When food is ready, people talk and write about it. But why do some people have a special voice in this? One philosopher says that tasting food is not a special skill, but some people are just better at describing it. Most studies on how we sense things focus on sight, not taste, and this should change. 
Food also has an artistic side. We say paintings or music are beautiful, but not usually food. Some philosophers think food should be part of art discussions, like sculpture or poetry. But food is eaten and gone, unlike art that lasts. 
There are many ethical questions about food. What should we eat: organic, local, vegetarian, or non-GMO? Our choices show our beliefs. Philosophers ask why we make these choices, and this is important to discuss. 
Cooking at home and in restaurants is different. Home cooks have a duty to their guests because of love and friendship. Everyone is included in the home kitchen. Professional cooks have duties to their boss and the food, so their kitchens are not open to everyone. 
A recent essay called ‘Diplomacy of the Dish’ talks about how food can help connect different cultures. We can learn to enjoy other cultures by eating their food and make friends by eating together. This has been important in international relations for a long time. The essay uses fun stories to show this part of food philosophy to readers.'

'Rob Daviau, from the US, makes special board games called ‘legacy’ games. He thought the board games he played as a child were not fun or challenging anymore. He wondered if board games could have a story. Could choices in one game affect the next game? He changed a classic board game called Risk to make Risk Legacy. In this game, choices have a lasting effect. Players might have to tear up cards or change the board. The game is played over several sessions, and past actions affect future games. Daviau also worked on a legacy version of Pandemic, a popular game where players try to stop diseases. His next game was SeaFall, set in the age of sail. Players explore and conquer new lands. Legacy game designers must think about all player choices to keep the story together. They use testers to see how the game works. Jaime Barriga tested SeaFall. He said it takes a lot of time. Sometimes the game works well at first, but later it breaks, and they have to fix it. Legacy games were not expected to be very popular. Daviau thought only a few people would like them. But many players, like Russell Chapman, loved the idea. He thinks it is a big step forward in game design. Ben Hogg, another fan, likes the adventure in legacy games. He says it is like watching a new movie each time. The legacy format is like video games and TV shows with episodes. Daviau wanted to be a TV writer but became a game designer. He likes telling stories. Pandemic creator Matt Leacock says making a legacy game is like writing a book. You need to know how it starts and ends. Daviau is happy to see others use his idea but thinks people will soon want something new. Colby Dauch, who works for the publisher of SeaFall, thinks the legacy format changes how we see board games.'

'One night, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He moved across the floor and went into a small drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story was shared a lot online. People enjoy stories like this because they like to think animals are like humans. Octopuses are very smart, even though they look very different from us. They can open jars, recognize faces, and use coconut shells as armor. Some people think it is unscientific to say animals are like humans. But Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies animals like gorillas and chimpanzees, says it is wrong to ignore the human-like traits of animals. He calls this 'anthropodenial.' He says animals can do many things we thought only humans could do, like thinking about the past and future, showing empathy, and understanding others' motives. In the past, people thought animals were smart. In medieval Europe, animals could even be put on trial for crimes. Charles Darwin, who created the theory of evolution, said the difference between humans and animals is not big. But in the 20th century, people started to see animals as simple machines. This was also a time when humans were destroying animal habitats. Now, de Waal believes we are starting to see animal intelligence as similar to human intelligence. He says the best tests for animal intelligence consider the animal's special skills. For example, squirrels can remember where they hide nuts, even if they fail human memory tests. In her book, The Soul of an Octopus, Sy Montgomery says if an octopus tested human intelligence, it might think we are not smart because we cannot change our skin color. De Waal is not sure if Inky really found his way to the ocean, but he knows stories like this help people appreciate animal intelligence. He once did an experiment with capuchin monkeys to see if they feel envy. When some monkeys got cucumbers and others got grapes, the ones with cucumbers got upset. A video of this experiment convinced many people of the findings. This shows how our minds work.'

'Robots were once only in science fiction stories, but now they are becoming very important in our world. Robots have been used in car factories for many years. Now, experts say robots will soon be used in many more areas, and many countries are not ready for this big change. Many people think robots will do most of the work humans do in the next 50 years. But, 80% of people also think their jobs will still be the same. This is not true. All work areas will change because of robots. For example, an Australian company, Fastbrick Robotics, made a robot called Hadrian X that can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour. This is much faster than two human workers. In San Francisco, a company called Simbe Robotics made a robot named Tally. Tally moves around supermarkets to check if goods are in the right place and priced correctly. People who like robots say they will create new jobs for people who can fix and program them. But some people worry that robots will take away the need for human skills. Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert in robotics, studies how robots will change jobs. He says that soon, many robots will be able to work with humans safely. In a few years, big companies will have a chief robotics officer, and some governments will make new laws about robots. In five years, salaries in the robotics field will go up, but many jobs will not be filled because there are not enough skilled workers. Dr. Zhang says people need to learn new skills because they cannot expect to do the same job forever. New robots will also be made for homes and will interact with us in new ways. This is a big chance for companies, but it also means we need new rules to keep us safe. With many jobs at risk, education is important to prepare for the future with robots. Countries need more people studying science, technology, engineering, and maths, known as STEM, to stay competitive.'

George Mallory, a famous climber, was once asked why he wanted to climb Mount Everest. He replied, "Because it's there." People often wonder why anyone would do something so dangerous. Mallory's answer might inspire some people to follow their dreams. It shows that climbing can be about adventure and fun. 
In 1967, a writer named Tejada-Flores wrote an important essay about climbing. He said there are seven different types of climbing, each with its own rules. Over time, this idea has become very popular among climbers. Many climbers love the feeling of freedom that climbing gives them. But climbing can also be difficult, like when a storm keeps you stuck in a tent. This shows a strange side of climbing: it can feel both freeing and limiting. 
Another climber, Joe Fitschen, thinks we should ask, "Why do people climb?" He believes climbing is in our nature. We like to take on challenges, even if they are risky. This means climbing is more about our biology than thinking it through. 
Brian Treanor, a US academic, says climbing helps us develop important qualities like courage and respect for nature. He thinks these are important in today's world. Climbing can help us grow and live better lives. 
Some climbers, like Ebert and Robinson, believe that climbing without help or technology is more challenging and deserves more respect. They think climbing alone is harder and riskier, but it can also be more rewarding. 
Climbing can also be about being in the moment and focusing on the task. This is similar to Zen philosophy, which teaches people to find peace in their minds. This is another reason why people might be drawn to climbing.

'For over sixty years, the pianist Alfred Brendel was very important in classical music. He was a serious and smart person who played and recorded many famous European piano pieces. He wrote and played a lot, but he did not teach much. People who knew him well saw that he could be fun, but he did not show this in his concerts. His life was full of study, travel, and playing music. 
Then, a few years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came to one of Brendel’s concerts and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel did not think it was a good idea. He had not taught many students before. He said, ‘You don’t ask a mountain guide to teach a child how to walk.’ But there was something special about Kit, who was about 14 years old then. Brendel listened to him play. Brendel said, ‘He played very well and from memory. Then he gave me a CD of a small concert he did, and he played so beautifully that I thought, “I have to make time for him.” It was a performance that was good from the first to the last note. It’s rare to find a musician like this.’
As Brendel is leaving the public stage, Kit is starting to enter it. Brendel is careful because he worries that Kit might get tired too soon. Kit, now 19, is always busy when not in lessons. He learns new languages, studies math, writes computer code, or plays tennis. His mother is always watching over him. He also writes music. Brendel says, ‘This is very important. Learning to read music is easier if you try to write it yourself. Kit has a great memory and can read music very well. More importantly, he listens to his own playing and to me when I explain something. He not only understands what I mean, but he can do it. And when I tell him one thing in a piece, he will do it everywhere in the piece where it comes later.’
Brendel is careful not to make people expect too much. He says, ‘I get upset if newspapers say Kit is the future great pianist of the 21st century. It’s not good to say that. It can be harmful. Like many talented young players, he can play some things very well, but others need more time and experience. It would be bad if a critic expected him to be perfect.’
Now, at 80 years old, Brendel is more relaxed. He says, ‘When I was young, I didn’t want to be famous quickly, but I wanted to do certain things by the age of 50. When I was 50, I had done most of those things, but I wanted to do more, so I continued. I don’t have the physical strength now, but in my mind, there are always things happening, pieces I’ve never played. I don’t play now, but it’s a nice new career.’'

'When I was little, I thought gardens were always beautiful places. Grandad’s garden was not in a dirty city. It was next to a river and went down gently to the water. You couldn’t reach the river, but you could hear the water and the birds in the trees. I thought all gardens were like this – a place to escape and find peace. Grandad’s garden was simple. He didn’t have a greenhouse, but some neighbors did. Their greenhouses were made from old windows. At home, my father was often quiet. He wasn’t boring. He liked funny things and had favorite phrases like ‘It’s immaterial to me’. He left school without finishing and became a plumber. He didn’t love plumbing. It was just his job. He and Mum once thought about moving to Canada, but they didn’t. He was good at fixing things at home, like making bookshelves. My parents moved house only once. But my mother liked to change furniture. One day, a piano came to our house. I wanted to like it, but it scared me. I liked the brass candlesticks on it, but my mother took them away. I never got to play the piano. My sister had lessons. When I asked my mother why I didn’t, she said, ‘You’d never have practised’. I liked the river best. I could imagine another world there. I would go with a fishing net and sandals that were too small. I’d look for fish to catch and take home. After trying to keep them alive, I put them back in the river. I wanted to leave school soon, but it seemed hard. One day, my father said, ‘There’s a job for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might like it.’ Dad didn’t like gardening, but he saw I loved it. I think he hoped it would be good for me.'

Lawrence MacEwen is on his Scottish island, the Isle of Muck. I am with him. The strong wind from the Atlantic Ocean is very powerful. It feels like it could blow us off the cliff and into the ocean below. MacEwen's sheepdog, Tie, comes close, and MacEwen gently pets him. The wind is loud, but MacEwen is comfortable on his island. He is showing me around. He points to the north and shouts, ‘That island is Eigg. The one to the west is the Isle of Rum. It gets twice as much rain as we do.’ I see rain clouds over Rum's big mountains. ‘Just beyond Rum is the island of Soay.’ Suddenly, MacEwen says, ‘I have sheep to move,’ as rain comes closer. We walk down the hill. As we walk, he tells me about the island: Muck is three km long and half as wide; its geese eat a lot of grass; and the MacEwens have lived here for 3000 years. Moving the sheep stops our talk. Tie, the sheepdog, is trying to move the sheep but not doing well. ‘Away to me, Tie. Away to me,’ MacEwen says, meaning the dog should go to the right. Tie goes straight into the sheep, causing confusion. ‘Tie,’ MacEwen says, sounding disappointed. ‘That will never do.’ The dog looks sorry. The Isle of Muck is mostly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence runs the farm with his wife, Jenny. Their son Colin, who is newly married, manages the island cottages. Their daughter Mary runs the island hotel, Port Mor, with her husband, Toby. Mary and Toby like that their two boys can explore the island and sail small boats in the summer. ‘They go out and come back only when they’re hungry.’ But living on the island has challenges. For example, electricity is only available sometimes. On my first evening, I wait for the lights to turn on. The next morning, I see Mary preparing breakfast with a flashlight. I get used to it, along with no mobile phone service. ‘There is mobile reception on the hill,’ Mary says. ‘Most people last a couple of days, then just put the phone away.’ So I do too. Everything on Muck seems surprising. Today, the boat brings groceries and three musicians with instruments. Their concert in the island’s tearoom is a big success, with everyone tapping their feet to the music. That night, by a warm fire, Lawrence MacEwen tells me how he met his wife, Jenny. ‘Her father bought a small farm on the isle of Soay from a newspaper ad, without seeing it. He had never been to Scotland. Jenny was sent to manage it.’ Did Jenny know about farming? ‘She had good typing skills.’ I go to bed with rain and wake up to more rain. But I eat well, with almost all the food from the island. Mary sends me to fisherman Sandy Mathers for fresh fish. I bring it back to Mary at the kitchen door. By 7 pm, our fish is on the table, and it is very tasty. Also uncertain is my ferry ride the next morning to another island. Many ferries were canceled in the last two months because of high seas. If my ferry doesn’t come, I will stay on Muck for two more days. Now, with or without a phone, I secretly hope for that.

'At first, the game design industry was mostly for computer scientists and people who taught themselves. It was not easy to enter. People often thought it was just a hobby for young people. But now, the video games industry is serious business. Experts are not surprised. Making video games is not easy. When a new movie comes out, video games based on it need many team members and months of hard work. Like many industries, it is hard to get into, but it is growing. Jim Donelly, who works for an online games magazine, says: ‘It’s hard to make progress in big companies or to change big games. But the industry needs game designers more than ever. Not just the leaders, but also the people who design parts of the game.’ So, how can you join this competitive industry? Many companies want people with a computer science degree, but Jim thinks differently. ‘There is only one way: make games. The tools are there. You need to make something to get a job. Game design is more than a job; it is a way of life. Like any creative work, you must do it to make it real.’ Another expert, John Field, has other ideas. ‘Just doing it is good, but it’s more complicated. Many want to work in games, but few meet the industry’s needs. Even fewer have the talent, skills, vision, and business sense to help the industry grow.’ Can you do it alone? ‘Maybe, but it’s hard,’ says John. ‘A good course in games can help and give support. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and move up. They like all kinds of entertainment and arts. They may have worked a few years after school and decided games are for them. They are not just fans; they are interested in the future of games. Connections can help too. To get ahead in games, you need to network.’ The idea of a young boy playing games all day is old. Now, games are for everyone. Families play together on consoles. Smartphones have many new games through apps and social media. John thinks there is room to grow. ‘Games are for big audiences. They are also a great way to learn. I see many new chances and opportunities in this big area.’

'Since I was a child, I have always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, but he didn't force me. I had a friend whose dad was very pushy. He always told my friend what he couldn't do. My friend could have been a good player, but he stopped wanting to play football. I am glad my dad was not like that. When I score a great goal from far away, people say it's just luck, but it isn't. I have practiced shooting from a distance since I was a kid. The best players in the world practice a lot, even if they have natural talent. Sometimes young players crash into each other, but I learned technique. When I teach kids, I tell them to enjoy learning skills. I used to play every sport at school, like rounders, baseball, athletics, and basketball. I know education is important, but football was all I thought about then. The teachers did a good job, but I didn't notice it at the time. I don't want it to be like that for my son. We try to read him books, but he is too young to sit still. I hope he doesn't just want to kick them around like a football. At the start of my professional football career, the manager helped young players like me join the first team. He didn't make a big deal about it, but we knew we had to prove ourselves. I scored in the first game of the season, but we lost. A TV presenter said, 'You can't win anything with kids.' That made us realize how much we had to do. We had some doubts, but we believed in ourselves as a team. I rely on close friends and family a lot. Having a lot of money can cause problems. People say, 'I can't believe you let your mother keep working.' I have helped my parents with money. I paid off their house loan and bought them a car. My family is strong and would not like to be on my payroll. My mum loves her job as a hairdresser, even if she doesn't earn much. I like to use my money to help people around me. I have a lot of money, but not as much as people think. After I stop playing, I want to take a year off to do things I couldn't do before. I want to go skiing right after I stop playing. I can't do that now because if I break a leg skiing, I can't play football, and I wouldn't be insured.'

'We were living at Reef Point because of Sam Carter. Sam was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. He helped us find a cheap place to live because my father could not write in Los Angeles. Sam was worried about losing money and clients. During the summer, the beach was empty because sea fogs covered the sun. Reef Point was not popular with day visitors. The road was not nice, and the nearby resort, La Carmella, was more attractive. People only came to Reef Point if they had no money or loved surfing. But now, with the hot weather, many people came. After months alone, we were surrounded by people and activities. My father was busy writing a script and was in a bad mood. I often went to the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty. We did not have a dog when we moved to Reef Point, but Rusty chose us. I gave him water, and he stayed. My father said, ‘He thinks we belong to him.’ Rusty loved the beach and brought me things he found. Sometimes, he brought things that were not his, like a new shoe or a towel, and I returned them. Rusty liked to swim with me, even though I swam faster. He never got discouraged. That day, my father went to Los Angeles to deliver his script. Rusty and I spent the afternoon swimming. As the sun set, we watched the surfers. One surfer was very good. She finished surfing and came to talk to me. She asked why I didn’t join them. I said I didn’t have a surfboard and no money. She asked if I was British and visiting. I said I lived there and my father was writing a film script. She asked his name, and I said Rufus Marsh. She knew his book, Tall as the Morning, and was interested in me after that.'

"‘What have I done?’ Violet Hetherington asked herself. She was standing in a long line at the dock in Southampton. The lines were very long and not moving. Her friend Annie had told her, ‘It’s best to get to the docks late. If you get there too early, you will wait a long time.’ Annie, who was married to a diplomat, traveled a lot and gave advice. But this time, her advice was wrong. After a while, an announcement said there was a ‘problem with the computer system.’ The people waiting were not happy. Some tried to be patient, some tried to be cheerful, but most were upset. They had paid a lot of money for this trip. This might be their last chance for some luxury. Not being able to get on the ship easily was not a good sign. Violet wanted to leave. She looked in her bag for her phone and saw it was missing. This was more annoying than the long lines. It made her feel that going on a cruise was a mistake. And now she had the problem of the phone. She couldn’t call the taxi company to check if she left it in the taxi, because the number was in her phone. Her older son Harry always told her to avoid this mistake. Behind her in the line was a friendly-looking couple. ‘I’m sorry, but I left my mobile phone behind. Could I borrow yours to make one call?’ Violet called Harry on the couple’s phone and left a message asking him to ask Kristina, her neighbor, to check if the phone was at home. If it was not in her flat, she would be in trouble, as she had no other way to find the numbers she needed in New York. Part of her thought, Thank goodness. But she did not tell Harry this. Harry thought he was wiser than his mother. Daniel, her younger son, was more understanding of her mistakes because he made them too. Dan might forget to give the message to Kristina. Finally, the lines started to move, and Violet gave her travel documents and got ready to go on the ship. Her heart sank when she saw the ship’s foyer. It looked like a hotel that tried to be fancy but wasn’t. There were shiny fake wood panels, big chandeliers, polished brass, and carpets like those in airports. Violet followed the signs to the ‘Elevators’ which had mirrors everywhere. The elevators were full of tired passengers who might not want to see themselves in the mirrors. Violet was pressed against the side of the lift as it went up, stopping at each floor to let people out. At last, on the twelfth floor, she got out. Her room had the balcony she wanted. She had been worried about what to say if it didn’t. Ignoring Annie’s advice to wait for a last-minute deal, she paid the most she could to be sure of the sea view."

'When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an auction, he did not know he was discovering the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof wanted pictures for a book about the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 images by Maier, a street photographer who took interesting pictures. Now, Maloof has a big collection of Maier’s work. In his home, he has her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, plus many 8mm movies and audiotapes. One morning, Maloof looked at all of it and realized he found something special by luck. ‘When I bought this, I didn’t know what it was,’ Maloof said. ‘I could have sold it all to someone else.’ Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon are learning about Maier’s life. They talked to families she worked for as a nanny and people from the shop where she developed her film. Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. In 1951, she returned to New York and in 1956 moved to Chicago to work as a nanny. Maier was a private person and always had a camera with her. She wore big coats, wide hats, and strong shoes. ‘On her day off, she would leave with her camera and come back late at night,’ said Maren Baylaender, whose husband hired Maier to care for his daughter. ‘She was private but had strong opinions about movies and politics.’ Maier knew a lot about theater and movies. She was not very social, but she liked to walk the streets with her camera and talk to people, sometimes recording them on audiotape. She was very focused on her ‘second job’, taking pictures of the world around her. ‘She was a true artist and did what she wanted,’ said Rydzon. ‘She didn’t let anyone stop her.’ Maier’s work is pure art; she did not do it for money. Her pictures often show women, children, the old, the poor, and abstract scenes. ‘Vivian’s pictures are very interesting,’ said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees the influence of other photographers in her work and wonders if she created her own style. ‘Was Vivian very skilled or did she copy ideas from others?’ Maloof wonders if he will ever look at all the negatives, which he keeps in three tall, fireproof cabinets. The funny thing is he was not interested in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her pictures, Maloof started taking his own photos. ‘As I learned more about photography and looked at her work again, I saw that people and street scenes were important to her,’ he said. ‘There was much more to her work than I thought. Now, we want to make her name known. To get Vivian Maier into the history books.'

'When a novel is called ambitious, it often means it didn't fully succeed. But this is not true for Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I talked to her in the UK when her book was very popular. She was calm, even though she was still in her twenties. She had just come from Germany and was going back to New Zealand the next day. She told me a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She showed her novel to the officer. The officer looked at it and asked, ‘What’s it about?’ This is not an easy question for an author. The Luminaries is set in the 1860s in New Zealand. Some crimes have happened, and 12 men meet to solve them. The story becomes very complex. Catton said she wanted to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but found the past gave more chances for problems for her characters. The book is over 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters enough attention. When I ask how it feels to be successful at a young age, she says, ‘It’s nice coming from a small country because everyone feels the success is partly theirs. People at home are very supportive.’ Then she adds, ‘It’s annoying when people think I’m not trying to do something philosophical in the book.’ Catton wanted to write the book in the shape of a spiral. Each part is half the length of the one before it. The book speeds up as it goes. I ask if it matters if the reader notices this. ‘I wanted to create a book with patterns that didn’t matter, but if you cared, you could see them,’ she says. Despite the book's structure, it is still an exciting murder mystery. Surprisingly, she says she didn’t plan the book beforehand. ‘I would write myself into a corner and then see how I could get out of it.’ She also wanted the book to be fun for the reader. We also talk about her love of TV drama series. I ask if she might want to write for TV. ‘That could be cool,’ she says. She is very enthusiastic and laughs often. She loves talking about her work and New Zealand. ‘When I come to Britain, I notice how my imagination changes just by being in a different place. I see why writers move away from New Zealand to busy places, to be around more people.’ But for now, New Zealand will stay her home. I hope it gives her ideas for more novels.'

'When Jonny Kinkead was a boy, he liked to make things in his dad’s garage and play the guitar. These two hobbies became his job for the last forty years: making steel-string, acoustic guitars by hand. ‘I still love the guitar,’ he says. ‘How can two pieces of wood make a beautiful sound? And by using different types of wood, you get different sounds? It still amazes me.’ Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven. At sixteen, he wanted to learn the bass guitar. ‘Some people would get a job and save money to buy one,’ he says. ‘But I thought if you wanted something, you made it yourself. I studied guitars and learned how different shapes and wood types changed the sound, and how to put them together.’ The bass was the first instrument Jonny made from scratch, but he and his brothers had been making other things for a long time. ‘We drew model boats and planes and then built them, so I knew the process. My father taught us how to use saws and sharpen chisels. I also fixed instruments for my friends.’ Jonny’s bass guitar was good, but he didn’t think about making guitars as a job. ‘I also liked painting and sculpture,’ he says. After school, he decided to study architecture at university. ‘Architecture is about design, which I liked, and being an architect seemed like a good idea,’ he remembers. But halfway through, he left. ‘I was too independent for it,’ he says. ‘But I left with a better idea of what I wanted to do. I still liked sculpture, but I realized guitar-making is like sculpture – it’s about shaping sound. And I thought it might be more practical than pure art because you make things people use.’ Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows part-time. The first guitars he sold only covered the cost of materials, but as he became known as a great guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, Jonny says he is ‘still just making a living’. He can only make ten guitars a year, which limits his earnings. In the early years, he worked hard to become known. He went to music festivals on weekends and got musicians to try his guitars and talk about him. He also had to learn how to price his guitars – when musicians asked, he didn’t know because it wasn’t natural for him. Jonny thinks it’s easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. ‘When I started, people thought the best acoustic guitars were made in the USA,’ he says. ‘UK-made guitars weren’t seen as good, even though we have always had good courses and skills here. But now our hand-made guitars have the reputation they deserve.’ Jonny says you can learn valuable techniques in class, and he thinks new instrument-makers should take courses. But he also believes there is no substitute for trial and error. ‘Look at other instruments, see what works or doesn’t, and try different things,’ Jonny says. ‘If you make the back too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. If someone else teaches you, you learn one way, but if you teach yourself, like I did, you learn everything.’'

'When English people talk, they often start with the weather. This is a tradition. A famous writer, Dr Johnson, said, ‘When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather’. This was true 200 years ago and is still true today. Many people think English people talk about the weather because they are interested in it. But this is not true. The American writer Bill Bryson says the English weather is not exciting. There are no tornadoes or big storms. The English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman says the weather is interesting because it is always changing. My research shows that both are wrong. English people talk about the weather to start conversations. When someone says, ‘Nice day, isn’t it?’ or ‘Ooh, isn’t it cold?’, they are not really talking about the weather. They are just starting a conversation. This is like monkeys grooming each other to make friends. English people use weather talk in three ways: as a greeting, to start a conversation, or when they don’t know what else to say. This makes it seem like they talk about the weather a lot. So, people from other countries think English people are very interested in the weather.'

Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain. She was trying to explain to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds how amazing it was that the Romans built a wall 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were interested because they chose this trip over trips to Spain, Greece, or France. They wanted to know why the wall was built, but Alice felt her answers were not good enough. She couldn't find a historical novel to help explain life at the Wall in Roman times, so she decided to write one herself.
Alice retired from teaching after 31 years and started writing in 2001. She felt it was a big change. Teaching was like acting, very demanding, but writing was exciting and less tiring. Her old teaching friends were jealous because she still connected with children through her books. Alice wanted her books to fill a gap in children's fiction. She thought many books for young people were about negative experiences or total fantasy, like Harry Potter. Her books were different.
Alice liked to teach English and History together, like teaching about ancient Greece with the novel Tale of Troy. She loved seeing children go from being bored to interested. Writing was like teaching for her. She started writing because there was a gap in the market and because her sons were leaving home. Her head teacher suggested she take a creative writing course, which surprised her. She didn't want to spend her summer on a course she thought she didn't need.
Before the course, she had to send her best piece of fiction. She quickly wrote a story about a Roman couple and their baby. The course students liked her story and suggested she publish it. With only school report cards as proof of her writing, she asked for a year off to write her first novel. Her husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and he helped her a lot. Alice says they work well together. He helps improve her writing by changing sentences and suggesting new words, while she likes to add more scenes.

'To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company asked brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to join a special race. The race was between a man and a car, and also between the two brothers. In the wild and hilly Yorkshire Dales in northern England, Jonny and his younger brother Ali would race to the same place. Jonny would drive a car on the roads, and Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. ‘I’m looking forward to it,’ Jonny said at the start line. ‘I’ve never done anything like this before: it’s exciting! These roads have beautiful views – and it’s very cold now, so I’ll be warm in the car.’ Alistair was also excited. He wore full winter cycling clothes, while Jonny wore jeans and a sweatshirt. Alistair was confident. ‘To be honest,’ he said, ‘I’ve seen his driving before, so I’m not sure he’ll make it. I might stop for a cup of tea halfway up.’ The race started at the beautiful Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and ended at Yorkshire’s highest road, Fleet Moss, 350 meters up. It was easy for the car, but Alistair had to climb a steep hill at the start. After a quick handshake, they began. Alistair rode his bike up the hill and across the countryside to Fleet Moss. Jonny got in the car and drove on the road. They would see each other again at the finish line. Who would get there first? Jonny’s confidence dropped quickly. Just 15 seconds into the drive, he faced a problem. A big tractor came out of a field and onto the road. ‘Welcome to Yorkshire,’ he said to the cameraman in his car. ‘If Alistair beats me, it’s because of this farmer!’ After the tractor moved, Jonny was back on the road. Alistair was having a hard time with the hill. He had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched him as he walked with the bike on his shoulders. Finally, he reached the top. On the other side, the ground was open, and the sun was shining. Alistair started to go faster. In the car, Jonny faced another problem. The roads in this part of Yorkshire are very old and narrow. Jonny had to drive slowly around a tight corner and through a stream on the road. After the last village, the road was straight to the finish line. Neither brother knew where the other was. As Jonny drove fast to Fleet Moss, Alistair was riding across his last field and back onto the road. He reached the finish line and stopped. Alistair looked up. ‘Is he here?’ he asked the crowd. ‘No? Really?’ He raised his arms in victory. Minutes later, Jonny arrived in the car. ‘Well done,’ Jonny said sadly. ‘I’m disappointed.’'

'The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your shot. The trimmed grass, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds make you feel separate from the outside world. The quiet of Centre Court helps my game. In a tennis match, I try hard to focus only on the game and the point I’m playing. The silence is broken by noise when a point is over: applause, cheers, people shouting your name. I hear them, but it feels far away. I don’t notice the fifteen thousand people watching every move my opponent and I make. I am so focused I forget there are millions watching me around the world as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, told me from a young age that this was the biggest tournament. By 14, I was telling my friends I’d play there one day and win. Before 2008, I played and lost, both times against Federer – in the final the year before, and the year before that. The loss in 2006 was not so hard. I was happy just to be there at twenty. Federer beat me easily because I didn’t believe enough. But losing in 2007 was very hard. I knew I could have done better, and it was my mind that failed me, not my ability. I cried a lot after that loss. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and lose it. Toni, who is a tough coach, usually doesn’t comfort me; he criticizes me even when I win. But he told me not to cry, that there would be more Wimbledons and finals. I told him he didn’t understand, that this was probably my last chance to win. I know the career of a professional athlete is short, and I want to make the best of it. Every moment counts, but some moments count more, and I let a big one pass in 2007. Toni couldn’t ease my sadness. Yet he was right. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I was sure I learned from that defeat; this time, my mind would not fail. The best sign was my belief that I would win. At dinner with family and friends the night before the final, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t tell them not to talk about it, but they knew I was already playing the match in my mind. Until the start of play, that space was mine alone.'

'A young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall went to Africa in April 1957. She wrote to her family, "I am living in the Africa I have always dreamed of." Jane spent most of her life in Africa. She became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society made her famous with articles and TV shows about her work with chimpanzees. Jane Goodall wrote many books, including a bestseller called "In the Shadow of Man," which has been translated into 47 languages. She is one of the most famous female scientists of the 20th century. Some people think her fame hides her real achievements. Many stories about her life focus on her adventures and dreams, but they do not always show what she really did. Jane Goodall is a pioneer in her field and a leading zoologist. She helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before her work, people did not know that chimpanzees ate meat or used tools. We also did not know that chimpanzees have emotions and social systems like humans. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe," is very important for chimpanzee research. Her study of wild apes in Gombe, Nigeria, is called one of the great scientific achievements. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves. Even as a child, Jane showed signs of her future career. When she was five years old, she disappeared one day. The police and her family looked for her. She came back with straw in her hair. She had been in a henhouse for five hours to see how hens lay eggs. This was the start of her interest in biology.'

'During our first conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using different voices. She sounds like a cheeky 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny old Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are known to people who watch children’s TV and cartoons, and to those who have seen computer programs about health and safety. ‘I’ve just done a voiceover about back injuries,’ she says, ‘so I had to quickly learn how to say many medical words.’ Shirley talks about what it takes to do voiceovers. ‘Many actors think they can do funny voices, and many of them can,’ she says. ‘But there’s more to it. You have to make the script come alive for people who can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions, but often they don’t get parts because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.’ After school, Shirley took a drama course to become a regular actor. During the course, she sometimes sang jingles for TV adverts. ‘One day,’ she says, ‘the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the part of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, amazingly, got a big part.’ Shirley realized she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. ‘Things just happened for me,’ she says. ‘In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character – and her brother and mother.’ Adult female actors often provide voices for small boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than male actors, and hiring child performers involves complex rules and many forms, which production companies want to avoid. Shirley has learned to make the right sounds from the back of her throat, and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the best part of a job that includes many things from educational videos to vacuum cleaner adverts. ‘Those are hard because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this job help,’ she says. ‘They’ve taught me that the trick is to smile while you're talking – that makes your voice sound bright and happy. When I do animation work, it feels like a holiday; working with other actors makes a big difference.’ The competition for work is tough, and a good showreel – a recording showing what the artist can do – is important. ‘It’s worth investing in a strong showreel,’ Shirley says. ‘There are agencies that help voiceover artists make them.’ She says she got where she is – near the top of her profession – through hard work as much as talent. ‘Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to all the film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practising your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.’ For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley recommends attending ‘specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.’ She also believes a love for human sound is important, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she is performing. ‘If I’ve been in the studio doing a certain kind of American voice, for example, it can take over me and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards,’ she says. ‘My children have grown up used to their mum talking in completely different voices.’'

'People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a job many kids dream about, like being a race car driver. But most people stop dreaming about these jobs and think about more realistic ones, like being a lawyer or making car parts. The idea that you can make money by drawing doodles like the ones in school notebooks seems silly. But some people do it. People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I loved comic strips as a child, drew for school papers, and was known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college and showed my drawings to different companies after I graduated. I was lucky to find a newspaper that needed political cartoons. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and soon I was making enough money to live on. You don’t need much to be a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even to be great at drawing. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. Being a cartoonist is hard. You shouldn’t try it unless you feel you can’t do anything else. It’s easier to get a regular job that pays the rent and gives you time for family and hobbies. The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I’ve done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I’ve also been a writer, a caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don’t say no to work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don’t really want. It helps to be smart, read a lot, and be curious about everything. What about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs with newspapers and magazines. But those days are almost gone. Now, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to make and sell your work. Cartoonists with good business skills often do better than those who are very artistic but not good at business. I often meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried they don’t let others see their work! To protect your work, just draw a little ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ put a circle around it, and write your name and the date. But it’s more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it’s not a disaster – it can be a lucky break!'

'Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out old things. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a black, Japanese-made guitar. I usually hate throwing things away, so why did I want to throw this guitar away? I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to put it on a pile of rubbish. Then, a young man came up to me and asked, ‘You’re not just going to throw that away, are you?’ I said yes, but I already felt a little regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said ‘Yes’. We went our separate ways. In the days and years after, I felt sad about what I’d done. Then, a few months ago, I got an email that changed my life. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it in a fish ten years later. That’s how I felt when I read this email from a man named Keith Rushton. He was a dealer and restorer of guitars. He said, ‘I’ve got your electric guitar.’ The guitar had been bought and sold many times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back. He used my name to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I almost cried. I would have given Keith anything he asked for, but his price was fair. I forgot that my dad put name-and-address stickers on everything, including my guitar. My dad would have laughed about this! My parents wanted me to learn the classical guitar in the 1970s because it was popular. I loved the sound of the classical guitar, but I couldn’t make much progress. So I switched to the electric guitar. This was also the time of punk music, when people who couldn’t play well could still be rock stars. When I got my old guitar back from Keith, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. It felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I held it sitting down, then stood up and put a strap over my shoulder. The electric guitar is played standing up. My fingers remembered how to play. I couldn’t draw a diagram of the chords, but my hands knew them. My fingers felt the pain of holding down the strings. The electric guitar is not really a solo instrument. Now that I’m learning it again, I think I’ll have to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone; maybe I can play with him. Or maybe there are other people my age who have had a similar experience. Maybe we could call ourselves ‘The Regainers’!'
