I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but never long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I was at the back of the slow group - not where I wanted to be. I watched faster swimmers moving ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first distance, and I was happy when I did it on my own. The next days were the same: jumping in, swimming at a comfortable speed, and stopping to look at the scenery. As the swims got longer, my speed and happiness also grew. We did not need the support boat much. I can’t wait to come again next year.'

'Being a flight attendant is not easy. But since I started the job, I have traveled a lot, from the US to Australia. I work with great people, I have a lot of free time, and life is never boring. This makes it a great job for a young person like me! As a child, I went to a boarding school in another country, away from my family. I always flew alone when school started and ended. I felt lonely, so I asked the flight attendants if I could help give out meals to passengers, and some said yes. I remembered this later when I wanted to leave my banking job and look for something new. At the interview, there were many young people, and many got the job. They were often very qualified like me and were changing careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say. I talked about my strengths and past work experience, not just that I loved to travel, because everyone says that. I got the job! I recommend this job to anyone because there are many good things about it. The free flights are not the best part. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying: 'no-one’s finished till everyone’s finished.' It feels like a big family. Even though we don’t see each other all the time, we are still close. When I am not working, I do not have to take work home. If I have difficult passengers, which is rare, I know the flight will end soon, and I will probably never see them again!'

'At the summer camp where I work, I like seeing the children do things they never thought they could do. Most children know how to swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for most of them. Some children feel very nervous, but after we encourage them, they try and reach the top. This makes them feel very happy. Some children miss home at the start of the week. It's not the very young ones who miss home the most – it's the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We don't let them use their mobile phones all the time. First, we say they can call home after lunch. Then, when they ask again after dinner, we say it's too late now, call tomorrow. Most children are fine after a few days, and at the end of the week, they thank us because they had a great time. Sometimes, it's not the children who feel lonely. We have parents who call a lot, asking how their child is doing, which is not needed. Often their child is busy playing games or doing something else, so we tell the parents to call back later. We often see a certain type of child come, usually wearing expensive new clothes. These children usually argue when we ask them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand why.'

'Rock the Planet is a musical show where actors also play music. It opened in London last year after five years in the USA, where it won ‘Best Musical’ four times! In the UK, it was hard to do the show with only British actors. This is because young actors in the UK can do fewer shows each week than in the USA. So, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Luckily, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. The theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA, and it is full every night. People want to hear the songs that were first popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. ‘It’s great that I get paid to play,’ he said, ‘especially on a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He told me how busy the young actors are. ‘We have school lessons every day at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ What do his friends think of the show? ‘My whole class came! The theatre has special ticket prices for schools. They loved it and that made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them,’ he explained. When I said I also play guitar, Jamie found another guitar and asked me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me, and I was happy when I finally played it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s skills and wished I could play like him. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! The young actors were already musicians, and some play many instruments, but none had played in a band before. They found it easy. Jamie said the hard part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were concentrating so much that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is really worth seeing.'
